title: 113_hr3584
content: The Act titled "Capital Access for Small Community Financial Institutions Act of 2014" allows privately insured credit unions to become members of a Federal Home Loan Bank. The Act "Capital Access for Small Community Financial Institutions Act of 2014" permits privately insured credit unions to join a Federal Home Loan Bank as insured depository institutions. The Act allows privately insured credit unions seeking membership in a Federal Home Loan Bank to be considered eligible for Federal deposit insurance if the State supervisor confirms their eligibility at the time of application. The Act allows privately insured credit unions to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance if the State supervisor confirms their eligibility at the time of application. If a determination is not made within 6 months, the credit union is deemed to have met the requirements. State law cannot avoid security interests of Federal Home Loan Banks in credit unions. The Act allows privately insured credit unions to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance if the State supervisor confirms their eligibility at the time of application. Federal Home Loan Banks have priority security interests in collateral for advances made to State-chartered credit unions. The Act allows privately insured credit unions to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance if the State supervisor confirms their eligibility at the time of application. Federal Home Loan Banks have priority security interests in collateral for advances made to State-chartered credit unions, giving them the same access as if the advance was made to a federally-insured credit union. Copies of audits of private insurers of certain depository institutions must be provided to supervisory agencies. Private insurers who are members of a Federal Home Loan Bank must submit audit copies to the Federal Housing Finance Agency within 7 days of completion. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the adequacy of insurance reserves held by private deposit insurers for entities insured by them. A report will be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, information on compliance with Federal regulations regarding the disclosure of a lack of Federal deposit insurance will be included for these entities.
